channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Pardoned Jan. 6 Rioters Rally and Demand More from Trump
item.description: The “J6ers,” as they refer to themselves, praised President Trump but called for more action from his administration, including financial restitution and prison reform.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters marched on the anniversary of Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol.

item.title: Court Questions Trump Administration Effort to End Temporary Protected Status for Haitians
item.description: A federal judge questioned whether the Trump administration appropriately reviewed safety conditions in Haiti before ending protections for people from the Caribbean nation.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:description: Judge Ana C. Reyes faulted the government for “selectively” using a line from a recent U.N. report to justify not extending Temporary Protected Status to Haitians, while ignoring a plethora of concerns laid out in the report about conditions in Haiti.

item.title: Stephen Miller Offers a Strongman’s View of the World
item.description: President Trump’s trusted adviser is casting his hard-right gaze abroad, saying the world must be governed by “force.”
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:description: Mr. Miller has the president’s complete trust, a staff of over 40 people, and several big jobs that include protecting the homeland and securing territories further afield.

item.title: Justice Dept. Memo Approved Military Incursion Into Venezuela as Lawful
item.description: The specifics of the memo are unclear. But Attorney General Pam Bondi told lawmakers in briefings this week that the administration would share the document with them.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.media:description: Nicolás Maduro was escorted off a helicopter to be taken to the federal court appearance in Manhattan on Monday.

item.title: Michigan City to Pay $3.25 Million After Woman Was Mistakenly Declared Dead
item.description: Timesha Beauchamp, 20, was found alive at a funeral home after she had been pronounced dead during a medical episode in Southfield, Mich. She died weeks later.
item.dc:creator: Mark Walker
item.media:credit: Erica Lattimore/Erica Lattimore through Fieger Law, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A lawyer for the family of Timesha Beauchamp said the city of Southfield had agreed to a settlement over the mistaken declaration of her death in 2020.

item.title: Tim Walz Says He Ended Minnesota Governor Run to Shield Residents From Trump
item.description: “I don’t think any governor in history has had to fight a war against the federal government every single day,” Gov. Walz said after ending his re-election bid.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño
item.media:description: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota at a news conference at the State Capitol on Monday.

item.title: Fire Ravages Los Angeles Motel That Played Supporting Role in Films
item.description: A city commission had just voted to consider the site of the old Hollywood Center Motel, which has long been vacant, for landmark status.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.media:description: A three-story building dating to 1905 that was part of the Hollywood Center Motel in Los Angeles was torn down after it was badly damaged in a fire on Sunday, the authorities said.

item.title: Ex-Turning Point Leader Gets Probation After Forging Voters’ Names
item.description: Austin Smith resigned from the group founded by Charlie Kirk and suspended his bid for re-election to the Arizona House in 2024.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:description: Austin Smith pleaded guilty in November to two criminal counts and admitted that he had submitted fraudulent signatures to state election officials.

item.title: Rubio Tells Lawmakers Trump Wants to Buy Greenland
item.description: President Trump has said since his first term that he wants to acquire Greenland, and he asked aides for an updated plan on Monday. European leaders reject the president’s assertions.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Tyler Pager and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A former radar station in eastern Greenland. President Trump has long said he wants to acquire the territory.

item.title: Judge Orders Halligan, a Trump Loyalist, to Explain Why She Has Kept U.S. Attorney Title
item.description: The ruling was the most robust effort to date to press the prosecutor, Lindsey Halligan, on why she has continued to serve as the U.S. attorney, despite an order throwing out her appointment.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer
item.media:description: A federal judge ordered Lindsey Halligan to explain why she continued to lay claim to her title after a different judge had determined that she was unlawfully appointed.

item.title: Suspect in Brown and M.I.T. Killings Discussed Attacks in Videos, Officials Say
item.description: Claudio Neves Valente, who is accused of killing two students at Brown and an M.I.T. professor, left rambling descriptions of the shootings.
item.dc:creator: Mark Arsenault
item.media:credit: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial outside the Barus and Holley science building at Brown University, where a shooting killed two people.

item.title: Trump Administration Posts False Jan. 6 Narrative on Riot’s 5th Anniversary
item.description: A new web page on the official White House site blames the Capitol Police and Democrats for the pro-Trump mob riot, absolving the president of responsibility and calling participants “innocent.”
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater and Alan Feuer
item.media:description: Rioters walking through the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.

item.title: Doug LaMalfa’s Death Further Depletes House G.O.P. Majority
item.description: The California Republican’s sudden passing, on the same day that Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene’s resignation took effect, made the party’s House math even trickier.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Doug LaMalfa, Republican of California, on his farm in Richvale, Calif., last month.

item.title: Georgia Schedules Special Election for Marjorie Taylor Greene’s Seat
item.description: The election on March 10, or a runoff in April, will determine who serves out the remainder of Ms. Greene’s term after her unexpected resignation from Congress.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas
item.media:description: Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene officially stepped down from her role on Monday.

item.title: Democrats Commemorate Jan. 6, Highlighting Trump’s Role
item.description: On Capitol Hill, Democrats spent the fifth anniversary of the riot forcefully rebutting the president’s attempts to rewrite the history of the attack, as he stepped up his false claims.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold
item.media:description: A special hearing on Tuesday included former members of the select committee that investigated the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol.

item.title: After Maduro’s Ouster, Marco Rubio Faces the Challenge of Running Venezuela
item.description: The secretary of state helped steer President Trump to attacking Venezuela and seizing Nicolás Maduro, and now aims to force the country to give U.S. companies access to its oil.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: A poor outcome in Venezuela could jeopardize Secretary of State Marco Rubio’s chances at higher office.

item.title: Maduro Invokes Prisoner-of-War Status, Echoing Panama’s Noriega
item.description: The argument worked for Manuel Antonio Noriega, who wore a uniform at trial and received special P.O.W. privileges after his conviction.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.media:description: Supporters of President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela demonstrating in Caracas, Venezuela, on Sunday. Mr. Maduro was seized by U.S. forces on Saturday.

item.title: Trump Warns of Impeachment if Republicans Lose Midterm Elections
item.description: President Trump is still sowing doubt about the integrity of America’s elections. The claims could affect this year’s midterms.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater and Dylan Freedman
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Donald J. Trump seen on a video screen during a rally at the Ellipse, a park near the White House, in Washington on Jan. 6, 2021.

item.title: Caltech, a Science Powerhouse, Hires Ray Jayawardhana as Its New President
item.description: Ray Jayawardhana, the incoming president, is an astrophysicist, but leaders at the California Institute of Technology also praised his credentials as a communicator at a time when science is under attack.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel

item.title: A Jan. 6 Rioter Returned to the Capitol Seeking Forgiveness
item.description: Pamela Hemphill, who said she rejected President Trump’s pardon for her role in the Jan. 6, 2021, attack, apologized to a Capitol Police officer who was assaulted during the mayhem.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:description: Pamela Hemphill, who five years ago participated in the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol, was back at the building on Tuesday to apologize for her actions.

item.title: American Federation of Teachers Sues Texas Over Educators’ Comments on Charlie Kirk
item.description: The lawsuit challenges a conservative effort to punish those who criticized Mr. Kirk in the aftermath of his killing.
item.dc:creator: J. David Goodman
item.media:description: Randi Weingarten, president of the American Federation of Teachers, at a protest last year in Washington, D.C.

item.title: Homeland Security Steps Up Enforcement in Minneapolis
item.description: U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement officials said the effort was its “largest operation to date.”
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo and Ernesto Londoño
item.media:description: Federal law enforcement agents making a traffic stop in Minneapolis on Monday. No one was detained.

item.title: Doug LaMalfa Is Dead: Republican Congressman From California Was 65
item.description: A Republican in the House since 2013, he portrayed himself as a voice for his constituents in his northeast district. His death narrowed his party’s slim majority in the chamber.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather and Kellen Browning
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Doug LaMalfa at his Northern California farm last month.

item.title: Tim Walz’s 17 Months in Politics Before Ending His Re-election Bid
item.description: Mr. Walz drew national notice when Kamala Harris chose him as her running mate. A fraud scandal derailed his bid for re-election as Minnesota’s governor.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
